channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Lawsuit challenges USDA demand for food stamp data as some states prepare to comply
item.description: The suit claims that efforts to get sensitive information about food aid recipients from states violates federal privacy laws.
item.content:encoded:
The suit claims that efforts to get sensitive information about food aid recipients from states violates federal privacy laws.

(Image credit: Spencer Platt)
item.dc:creator: Jude Joffe-Block

item.title: Proposed Muslim development in Texas brings inquiries by DOJ and state officials
item.description: The project, known as EPIC City, has yet to break ground, but members of this Muslim community feel stereotyped.
item.content:encoded:
The project, known as EPIC City, has yet to break ground, but members of this Muslim community feel stereotyped.

(Image credit: Yfat Yossifor)
item.dc:creator: Caroline Love

item.title: Voice of America's prospects appear grim after appeals court order
item.description: A federal appeals court said it would not intervene — at least for now — to thwart the Trump administration's plans for the near-total dismantlement of Voice of America.
item.content:encoded:
A federal appeals court said it would not intervene — at least for now — to thwart the Trump administration's plans for the near-total dismantlement of Voice of America.

(Image credit: Bloomberg)
item.dc:creator: David Folkenflik

item.title: Two Israeli embassy staffers killed amid a rise in antisemitism
item.description:
Yaron Lischinsky and Sarah Milgrim worked for the Israeli embassy in Washington, D.C.

This weekend, they were slated to go to Jerusalem — Milgrim was to meet Lischinsky's family for the first time. According to Israeli ambassador Yechiel Leiter, Lischinsky had bought a ring and was planning to propose.

Instead, they were gunned down outside an event at the Capitol Jewish Museum on Wednesday night.

The killing comes aside a rise in antisemitic incidents. Daniel Shapiro, a former U.S. ambassador to Israel, reacts to the news.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
Yaron Lischinsky and Sarah Milgrim worked for the Israeli embassy in Washington, D.C.

This weekend, they were slated to go to Jerusalem — Milgrim was to meet Lischinsky's family for the first time. According to Israeli ambassador Yechiel Leiter, Lischinsky had bought a ring and was planning to propose.

Instead, they were gunned down outside an event at the Capitol Jewish Museum on Wednesday night.

The killing comes aside a rise in antisemitic incidents. Daniel Shapiro, a former U.S. ambassador to Israel, reacts to the news.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

(Image credit: Tasos Katopodis)

item.title: The U.K. hands Chagos Islands over to Mauritius but says it will secure a U.S. base
item.description: The Chagos Islands are in the middle of the Indian Ocean and home to a strategic military base on Diego Garcia.
item.content:encoded:
The Chagos Islands are in the middle of the Indian Ocean and home to a strategic military base on Diego Garcia.

(Image credit: U.S. Navy)
item.dc:creator: Fatima Al-Kassab

item.title: White House agrees to keep migrants in Djibouti for now, blasts federal judge's ruling
item.description: The judge says the administration "unquestionably" violated his earlier order, which stated migrants cannot be deported to a country other than their own without having adequate notice and a chance to object.
item.content:encoded:
The judge says the administration "unquestionably" violated his earlier order, which stated migrants cannot be deported to a country other than their own without having adequate notice and a chance to object.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Jasmine Garsd

item.title: Texas Muslim community's proposed new development prompts investigations
item.description: The U.S. Department of Justice and top state officials are investigating a proposed Muslim housing development in North Texas known as EPIC City for potential religious discrimination. The project's developers say they're years away from breaking ground.
item.content:encoded: The U.S. Department of Justice and top state officials are investigating a proposed Muslim housing development in North Texas known as EPIC City for potential religious discrimination. The project's developers say they're years away from breaking ground.
item.dc:creator: Caroline Love

item.title: Why did university police chase a student and his baby across a graduation stage?
item.description: Jean Paul Al Arab and his 6-month-old led police on a brief foot chase during a University at Buffalo ceremony. The school said the grad violated rules about who can participate in the commencement.
item.content:encoded: Jean Paul Al Arab and his 6-month-old led police on a brief foot chase during a University at Buffalo ceremony. The school said the grad violated rules about who can participate in the commencement.
item.dc:creator: Alana Wise

item.title: Supreme Court allows Trump to fire members of independent agency boards — for now
item.description: At issue is President Trump's firing of NLRB member Gwen Wilcox, who still has three years left on her term, and Cathy Harris, who still has four years left on her term as a member of the MSPB.
item.content:encoded:
At issue is President Trump's firing of NLRB member Gwen Wilcox, who still has three years left on her term, and Cathy Harris, who still has four years left on her term as a member of the MSPB.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: Vaccine advisers to the FDA recommended changes to COVID vaccines
item.description: Advisers to the Food and Drug Administration met Thursday to help decide which variant of the virus that causes COVID should be targeted by updated versions of the vaccines.
item.content:encoded:
Advisers to the Food and Drug Administration met Thursday to help decide which variant of the virus that causes COVID should be targeted by updated versions of the vaccines.

(Image credit: Sarah Silbiger)
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein
